reviews.review_text: This is the most fun that I've had with a spaceship-based combat game since Freelancer and, before that, X-Wing vs Tie Fighter. I have not beaten it yet, but these are my impressions so far.  The Good:      The PRICE. This game plays like a $60 AAA title.     Fast-paced combat in capital ships that actually includes you piloting instead of just giving commands.     Main storyline makes you want to learn more.     QWERTY controls are downright elegant - I own a controller but have no desire to use it.     No Z-Axis - I understand some people refuse to buy the game for this reason but, not only is it unnecessary, it would also make the game extremely awkward considering the types of ships you're flying. You won't miss it, trust me.     Young game, but so far, almost entirely bug free.     Epic blues soundtrack that changes songs depending on what you're doing in game. Fast music for fights, cruising music for, well, cruising.     The game world feels like Firefly would if it would have had a lot more in-space pewpew and also aliens. Lots of aliens.     Enough ship customization, but not so much that you feel like you need an encyclopedia. (looking at you, EVE)     Bits and pieces of humor throughout.     Graphics are pretty, if not necessarily stunning.      The galaxy is persistent, living, and breathing, and things are happening that have nothing whatsoever to do with you, which can cause interesting results.   The Not-As-Good:     They're not planning on expansions or DLC or anything, last I heard, and there have been zero updates to the game since launch, though that was only 15 days ago. I'd like to think there's a big content patch in the works or something, but I have no evidence for that. The game is, however, absolutely stable, as far as I can tell, so maybe they're just considering it finished. (edit - as of 11/17/15, they have released a small patch)     Running missions to keep your ship powerful enough to take on the next story element might be too reptitive for some, though I'm enjoying it.     Escort missions are still kind of broken. I just did one where my client's destination was to a base that was aggressive to him, presumably because the base was aggressive to me. I don't know any reason a merchant would purposely go to a station whose defenses were going to shred him. On the first attempt, there was also a BIG fleet, and I didn't get credit for the mission because he got blown up. On the second attempt, no fleet, so although the station's defenses opened fire on us both, I got credit for the mission just before the merchant ship exploded. So I looted him and flew off, getting both the merchant's cargo and the pay for the escort. Amusing, but obviously not what the developers intended.   Is this worth your $20? Absolutely. Zero question. Even if you don't particularly like these types of games, the lack of Z-axis might actually do it for you. It makes the game feel a lot less nauseating to those who typically can't handle the extra plane, and eliminates the circling buzzard effect that tends to plague starfighter-based games (Elite: Dangerous, looking at you).   There's something about running straight at a ship three times your size, turning and opening up your cannons and just shredding them that is immensely and uniquely gratifying while some fast-paced, hard-core electric guitar plays on queue, and the pirate-lord screams 'No...no-no-no-NO!' then blows up, leaving behind a rare piece of ship equipment.

I'm not really sure when space westerns became a thing. My secret inner weeb wants to point to Cowboy Bebop or Trigun, but it just as easily could have been Firefly or Starcraft or something else entirely. They're the logical conclusion of humanity expanding into space, really, embracing the freedom of an open universe without the unity or enlightenment of something like Star Trek. This is precisely where Rebel Galaxy lives, in a simple wild west approach to space battles and exploration.  You begin the game by inheriting an old junk freighter from your aunt and running errands in it for an old alien acquaintance of hers. Following the main story missions unravels a lengthy, familiar tale of deep space intrigue and ancient artifacts. This is of course only one option of many in the vein of something like Sid Meier's Pirates! because you can just as easily haul cargo, claim bounties, or pirate convoys for as long as the game holds your attention. A fair spread of ships, weapons, and upgrades are available across several factions for you to spend your hard-earned credits on and advance in power.  The moment-to-moment gameplay of Rebel Galaxy is like an arcadey version of naval combat. Capital ships in this sci-fi reality still rely on broadsides for most of their firepower, so you'll be sidling up to just about everything you want to blow away. You also get auto-targeting turrets and a secondary weapon that can fire missiles or flak, as well as shield and speed boosters to expand your tactical options. I wouldn't say there's a lot of depth to the combat but positioning and prioritizing targets can mean the difference between victory and the cold embrace of hard vacuum.  Unless you get really into the mostly generic story you're going to want to spend most of your time amassing wealth for bigger ships and guns. There's a basic commodity system you can play space trader with that requires some attention to trade routes and emergent events, but most of your time will probably be spent on missions. Each station has a mission board offering bounty collections, blockades, pirate hunting, cargo hauling, and more. These missions are assigned a difficulty based on your ship's current loadout, which is terribly helpful because anything above Average carries a very real chance of annihilating you in an instant.  Rebel Galaxy offers a very promising setup and world to prosper in but suffers from a few issues, the difficulty curve being chief among them. At some point you're going to hit a wall where your next story mission or the only profitable missions are High or Very High risk, and if the enemy composition is not favorable to your particular ship you're going to die very, very fast. Upgrading to a larger ship is the easiest way to climb the difficulty curve but can require a LOT of side missions and busywork if the next hull in line isn't very cheap. People who are easily distracted and habitually clear side missions will fare a lot better than most here.  The further you get the more technical issues you'll see crop up as well. Late in the game I started having mission-critical items disappear and enemy ships not properly register as objectives, which led to some aggravating wastes of time. There's also a lot going on in every star system, with pirates and militia lurking everywhere. This sounds cool at first but missions don't account for or clear existing entities in the mission space, so a Low risk battle against some frigates can turn out to be instantly fatal if the game decides to spawn pirate dreadnoughts in that particular sector.  I've had my fair share of frustration with this title, but most of my time in it has been a relaxing and rewarding romp around the galaxy. The systems you explore are expansive, colorful, and full of debris fields and nebulae to explore for secrets and bounties. Warping around has a great feel to it, with rich engine sounds and visual distortions through space. The twangy western feel is out in full force as well, with plenty of rough-spoken captains to deal with, junky ships to pilot and pilfer, and plenty of wailing country rock to fill the silent void.  At times it feels very much like a friendlier, simpler, offline EVE Online, though it never really matches the same sense of scale or vastness. I mean that in the best and worst ways, too, because it never really aspires to be more than a basic space hauling shooting gallery. And yet, there's an undeniable draw to scraping together the credits to land a new class of vessel and taking it out for a spin in the places you feared to tread before. That's where Rebel Galaxy really succeeds, in giving you a universe to explore and plenty of reasons to see it all.

26 hours in and I'm basically in world 2.   When I play this game, I keep thinking that this is what Freelancer should have been. When I played Freelancer, I had a 'was that it?' feeling. Contrarily, Rebel Galaxy gives off a 'not JUST a space flight adventure simulator' sort of vibe.  Yay: - Ignore the story, earn money, buy really big ships. - Ability to join multiple guilds without needing to quit your current one - Broadside combat in a space sim is surprisingly fun. - Very responsive devs, check the bug reports part of the forum - Prices of commodities go up and down in response to world events and planetary type - Wide variety of missions. Escort, Pickup, Delivery, Blockade Running, Head hunting... - No speed lanes, you want to get somewhere fast just point your nose and punch the warp. - Dynamic system. In Wing Commander: Privateer, you could watch the news and respond accordingly to major events. Is there a famine? Bring food. War? Bring weapons. Market glut, buy low. This system is rarely found in these space trading games. I don't think Freelancer had it. - Good voice acting - Intuitive game design - Aliens! - Varied Nebulas. Including the classic ones like lightning nebulas that can shatter your shields in a single flash and dark nebulas where danger and mystery lurk within. - Scanner. A nifty halo emits from your ship and lets you know of nearby enemies, allies, and items.  Nay: - Broadside combat is rather easy. Just manuever until your side is exposed, use precise targetting, and press a button. The lead is automatically calculated for you. The only thing you need to decide is how much time to charge the shot. - Fighters are so annoying since they can go to the 3rd dimension. Plus the strike craft defense options are a bit lacking due to their extremely limited range. You're left with relying on general-purpose turrets to pick off the pesky gnats one at a time. - No speed lanes. Most of the time, I neglect to plot a proper course before warping so I end up going through like 3 asteroid fields, 2 debris fields, and 1 planet. That's like hitting 6 red lights when you're trying to get somewhere.  Meh: - No idle radio chatter - From what I've played so far, you pass lots of planets but there is no planetary landing. You always stop at a station in orbit. I'm guessing the idea is that space ships should stay in space where they're designed to work.

PROS: -Combat is amazing fun and engaging, combat is fast and the explosions are satifying -your ship feels like a formula 1 racer in the emptiness of space -space isn't that empty in this game -ships feel huge unlike a lot of titles the capital ships feel like a force of power -free to do as you please -better story than most  CONS: -trading is not that great a career as a trader is silly due to being a little profit career -characters are not memorable, even if the voice acting is miles above other space titles -missions are kind of repeating killing and shipping things -the starter ship really doesnt show the games golden eggs  OVERALL: great title totally worth 20 bucks I'd say 8/10, hoping for DLC or Rebel Universe (Rebel Galaxy 2) :D

Imagine you're playing Assassin's Creed IV: Black Flag. Now, imagine that instead of being stuck with that one, tiny, but somehow infinitely upgradable little ship, you can actually buy new ships as your fortunes improve. Now, imagine you're in space. Finally, imagine you don't have to get out of the ship to follow some British ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ around the island for 20 minutes in an area that is suddenly, inexplicably teeming with soldiers.  I think I got sidetracked. Anyway. This is an excellent quasi-3D ship combat game. Not a full 3D sim like Freelancer... all player-piloted ships, and those of similar size, seem to occupy the same plane of space. Rolls, climbs, and dives are not valid maneuvers. Shields go fore, aft, port, starboard, with no concern for doral or ventral. Despite this, you don't feel particularly limited in your play. It's just streamlining something that can overly complicate some other games.  There is some downside. There isn't a lot of variety to your available weaponry. The targeting AI that controls your turrets most of the time is kinda stupid, and works in exclusive terms, rather that allowing prioritization. There are, inevitably, escort missions, some of which you will lose for no good reason. The in-game economy is a little capricious, which makes moving goods profitably as a trader a bit of a long game. But I still find it enjoyable to spend a few hours making pretty explosions in space, set to a soundtrack that you might find playing in Jim Raynor's house back on Mar Sara- forgettable, upbeat, twangy rock.
If Firefly was a game, this would probably be it.

Honestly, there's nothing wrong with this game. However, after 17 hours in...I felt nothing. It was cool as first. The music got me hyped up, the fighting was...meh. The ship only navigates on 1 plane...but we are in SPACE! So the combat and the movement seems kinda lackluster and once you get passed the cool music you start to realize that the game is super repetitive, kinda bland, and just lacking in life. It's not a bad game by any means, but not something I'd pay full price for, especially when there's other space-shooty-grindy games out there.   You want space? Play Elite:Dangerous or something. This is Elite:Lite and Low Fat.  Only get it on sale for like...under $10.00

This game absolutely has that 'one more mission' feel about it, typically my 'one more mission' ends up being a dozen more! It's very easy to get into, and to be honest there isn't a massive amount of depth to it, but what it does, it does well. If you like very open games that reward you for being willing to work to your goals in a manner of your choosing (trade, combat, mining) then this is a good example. If you're looking for in depth storytelling and characterization, you might want to look somewhere else.

Not sure if it's because I'm a Firefly fan or what, but man, this game is just plain amazing. There's so much to do and once you get the hang of things you will find that the game has even more to offer.

Gonna keep that review simple. It is a good game which may keep you busy for 20-30 hours. It has a pretty low replayability though as there is very little interest in restarting the game from scratch (the story missions give you 2 different minor bonuses to choose from on 2 occasions).  So about the game, it is a pretty standard space opera trading/combat game and has all you could expect from the genre. Its (only) originality lies in you controlling capital ships (from the small and fast corvettes to the massive and powerfull dreadnoughts) and having 3 sets of weaponry (broadsides, turrets and a tertiary weaponry). Making money can be achieved through a variety of quests, piracy, bounty hunting, helping attacked merchants, mining, looting and of course trading. It is grindy, but fair.  Overall it is a solid title and I recommend it for what it offers which is a couple dozens of hours of fun (I have more on record because I deleted a save by mistake).
This is such a great game. My only complaint would be that I want more of it. Hopefully the devs will either open it up to modding support of provide expansions.

You can change your tactics depending on your preferred style of play, your weapons, and a slew of other interchangeable options that allow you to specialize your ship. I honestly don't want to give too much away. The combat is so much fun and it's running at 3840 res well over 100 fps. The graphical rewards are awesome! Buy it!

Highly recommended for space pilots, space pirates, and especially, space pilot pirates.  tl;dr: Firefly with capital ships by a well-credentialed indie developer (i.e, Torchlight). Elite Dangerous in an arcade, but still mature, setting.  Pros: + Great polish in graphics. Crunchy, but colorful. Just the right amount of JJ lensflare. + Excellent, excellent, excellent sound design. Audio feedback is excellent. Soundtrack fits perfectly. + Varied ship customization. Even the starter ship can be outfitted for very, very different roles. + Thank you for on-screen button reminders! For a casual, 'old fart' gamer... that's huge! (It's not memory loss... not yet... it's only playing 20 minutes a night) + Broadside combat maneuvering is great! Many 'Age of Sail' ship games don't do broadside maneuvering as well as Rebel Galaxy does it.   Cons: + Minor Nit: Some odd UX choices. Radial menu has most of what you need, scan button has others, and yet the start menu has even others. + No multiplayer. Wow, would this be fun in a team! I get that it would be out of scope for this sorte, ala Torchlight 1. + Another minor nit: Who are the factions? Are they important? Not sure. A few brief pop-ups when you gain/lose standing might help.  For <$20, I highly recommended buy for spaceship fans and browncoats alike. A nice hybrid of space sim and space shooter.

I bought Rebel Galaxy on a whim, and thus far it has been the best impulse buy I've ever made on Steam. You control a space cruiser flying around the galaxy trading and fighting. Make money from trading at space stations buying low, selling high, and use the money to upgrade your ship with new weaons, armor, and equipment. This will allow you to take on pirates (or become a pirate) and loot your fallen enemies. Trade, fight, loot, upgrade, repeat until you have enough for a bigger ship and repeat the process. This is much what I imagine Han Solo and Chewbacca did before running into Luke and Ben in Mos Eisley. Do you want a Han Solo simulator or a Firefly simulator? This is pretty much it. I also enjoy the amount of choices the devs chose to throw at the player. For almost every mission you have multiple options of how to proceed, be it violently or non-violently. I have yet to see how many of these choices play out, but Rebel Galaxy has made a very good impression in my first few hours of gameplay.

I bought this game because of the trailer set to 'Evil Ways: Justice Mix,' and I have no regrets. Whether intended or not, the title is a loving tribute to all 'Cowboy Movie In Space' stories, from Star Wars to Firefly. As with any other similar offering, the startlingly addictive travel-fight-upgrade loop is crafted to keep you hooked, and hooked I was.  'Rebel Galaxy,' at the pick-up-n-play level, offers a nifty sort of subversive, stripped-down take on maneuvering and shooting. This isn't a game about twisting and turning in every possible direction. Instead, you're locked on a 2D plane, with your abilities to both manage your loadout and hop into manual fire-control being of paramount importance. This is not to say that maneuvering and mobility aren't influential. Rather, it's to say that the approach to those aspects is much more focused; The 'domain' is restricted to a relatively simple mechanic that's easy for the player to recognize and iterate upon.  What's very interesting to me is how this connects to the overall backdrop of the experience. Especially with the 'broadsides' element, the way the ship-combat works makes that part of the game a 'Tall Ships In Space' sort of activity, which is usually mutually exclusive from the 'Cowboy Movie In Space' genre. An odd sort of outcome, though, is that for all the emphasis on the broadsides, the game ends up subverting them. Matching speed and hammering away at an enemy is fine if you outclass them, but you're far better off getting on their tail and letting your turrets do the work. A smaller ship can really beat up on bigger adversaries that way, because the truly frightening firepower can't hit you.  'Rebel Galaxy' doesn't quite hit a perfect mark. The way the interaction is broken up into three modes is strange and clunky, with two kinds of scanning (the pulse and detail scans) being strangely divorced from each other in both where they are found and how they work. Also, the 'loot' value/ mission value/ mission difficulty/ equipment cost curves start off being very nicely tuned, but then seem to diverge as the game gets into the late stages. Particularly frustrating were missions labeled as being relatively safe, where that label apparently pertained only to the very beginning of the mission. A few moments into the actual meat of the encounter, and you might find yourself surrounded by a large number of very dangerous opponents.  The problems are very small, though. 'Rebel Galaxy' is a truly worthy effort that is fun to play and manages to have its own identity. I hope there are more like it over the horizon.

As a fan in general of the larger and more complex space sims such as the old X games I can say I had a lot of fun with this game despite it being 'simpler'. If you're looking for a game that is very deep and has fully fleshed out trading, reputation, 3d flight you may want to look elsewhere (X3 or Starpoint Gemini 2 come to mind). I don't think that's what the developers were trying to accomplish here. I think they wanted the fun and engaging nature of a naval pirate game with some light-weight trading mechanics, where the focus is kept on the combat with the loot system basically for rewarding the player and enabling progression. In that I think they succeeded and did a great job in bringing that feel to a space setting while adding a distinctive feel with the music and pace. I will say that I did have a minor issue with the game where once I found the right setup it became pretty easy to cheese my way through the fights, but it was still a blast.

A space game with lots of great concepts, the only problem seems to be due to the fact that it was mostly done by 2 people. The only problem I've had with this game is that faction reputation scores don't seem to give the effect that I expected them to. For example if I got my reputation upto 'Friendly' with the militia, I would expect them to be friendly with me when I hail them and so far I got the same response I used to get back when I was still in neutral. Other than that it is a great game, you can ally yourself with citizens and militia or be a pirate shooting up citizen and milita ships. Combat is well done and there's different types of ships and gear that you can fit it with. There's also an option to hire mercenary to fight along with you and there's a nice economy simulation under it all. And finally soundtrack really fits with the game, has space-western vibe to it.   In conclusion, get this game you wouldn't regret it.

Takes the fun/addictive elements of freeform space sims while avoiding the over-complexity of some of these titles (such as the X-series). As usual you start with an underequipped ship and earn money for better weapons/systems, new ships, and even mercenary support if you want it. You can earn money via missions (randomly generated and storyline), trading, mining, piracy or bounty hunting; it's up to you if you want to stay the right side of the law or if you aim to misbehave. It's worth noting that your starting ship is a corvette and the ship classes only get bigger from there on (right up to massive dreadnoughts). Because you're always commanding a large ship, combat is very different from a fighter-focused space sim and as others have pointed out it the 2D movement gives a 'naval battle in space' feel to it (though faster paced); it actually works pretty well, making the battles very fun to play - which is a good thing, because there is a lot of combat in this game.  Visually this has a beautiful-looking universe, some spectular space battles and a wide variety of nice ship designs (from Serenity-style rustbuckets to more conventional-looking starships). I like the fact that the different ships cater to different playstyles - bigger isn't necessarily better as there are other factors like speed, manouverabilty and weapon placement, so instead of a linear progression to the 'best' ship, people will find their own favorite ships along the way.  There are some aspects of the game that could do with some improvement such as the scaling of encounters and missions - the actual difficulty of missions doesn't always seem to match the stated risk level. Also it's quite possible to get into fights where the only chance of survival is to run, especially at the beginning of the game; though this is not a bad thing in itself, the fact that the game pops up a combat tutorial note on your first fight (even if you're totally outmatched) could confuse new players into thinking they should always be able to win their first battle. I can see why the single checkpoint-type save is controversial, but personally I'm fine with a single save AS LONG AS there is some backup in case of corrupt saves - fortunately haven't had a corrupted save yet, but would be pretty peeved if this happened after hours of play.  The hillbilly rock soundtrack does help create that 'wild frontier' Firefly vibe, but it also starts to get a bit old after about 10 hours - fortunately there is an option to stream your own music - this is a great feature that allows you to select different music sources for different situations (ambient, combat, idle, station etc).  Overall this is probably the most enjoyable space game I've played since Freelancer.

Pretty close to being a really solid game. I'm going to recommend it over all, with the suggestion you pick it up on sale at some point.   Pros:  -the space combat is pretty fun -the soundtrack is great -fairly robust quest system -good options for making a lot of money regardless if you prefer mining, trading, or combat  Cons: -Main quest is super short, consisting of about 8 'go here kill these guys' missions. -Although there are tons of options for side quests, they get old pretty quickly. -40 hours of play time and everything is done, got a dreadnaught with maxed out gear, mostly special pirate/virilax loot gear, about 30 million creds in the bank on top of that, and just pretty much bored with it. I will miss the soundtrack, though.  Just the game itself I'd give it 5/10, but if you can get it on sale for 5-15 bucks it's worth it if you're in to this sort of game.

I'd call this a light recommendation. There's a great deal of repetitive game play, but I found that for the price it met exactly what I wanted: a space game with some space fights that made me feel like a space ace. The story-line is intriguing, but there are some stoppages as you have to upgrade your ship as you progress or it will not be powerful enough for the missions. Despite the somewhat repetitive nature, there was a certain appeal to finally getting that new ship and whipping the ♥♥♥ of those pirates that took you into hull so many times. Treat this game like it's Gran Turismo, Space Edition, and you'll probably solidly like it as I did. Game is 8/10. EDITED because I forgot to mention, the MUSIC is AWESOME. Totally makes you feel like you're in Firefly. There's only a few different songs, but they are masterfully done and very immersive. Music is 10/10.

I have loved the space game genre since I was 8 years old. The fact that I am recommending this means that out of the 95% of released space sim titles I have played to death, Rebel Galaxy manages to stand out a cut above many of them. I am not even a quarterway finished with the main storyline, yet 10 hours in, the amount of content is quite impressive, and makes gameplay enjoyable to say the least.   First and foremost, this is a third person spaceship simulator. There is no empire building or 4X gameplay involved.   You primarily fight, trade and explore in Rebel Galaxy, and start off doing the main campaign which you can deviate from at anytime. Of course the campaign has you flying around a little bit to do other things, but fighting is usually involved. Wonderful thing here is though, interactions with NPCs in the campaign and in general allow for non-violent alternatives to do a mission, or, for instance, to handle a pirating attempt or an illegal cargo inspection by system militia.   There are about a dozen solar systems in Rebel Galaxy, so you are given some wiggle room to move around. Content such as missions, NPC spawns, and solar system events are randomly generated. There is enough variety to keep things from going stale, and as you get farther away from your starting solar system, more content (ships, equipment, guild allegiances) is available to you.  Combat is a bit different in Rebel Galaxy. And your ship's motion is limited to 2D movement only (while fightercraft and the environment objects can have 3D motions and positions). I will seperate this into two parts. Offensive capabilities and Defensive capabilities.   Offensive capabilities  Includes 1) A primary weapon 2) A secondary weapon 3) Turret systems 4) Mercenaries 5) Deflectors.    Primary weapons can be either pulse laser types or beam laser types. You fire broadsides (i.e from the side) at the enemies on either side. Very powerful, and include a small charging time for an auto-aim accuracy bonus.    Secondary weapons are either mines or missiles (point & shoot or seeking). Good damage.    Turret systems can be either pulse or laser types. You can take control of your turret groups (1 at a time only) and fire at enemies in a 360 degree arc. Critical against fightercraft and provide good sustaining damage against larger craft.    Mercenaries are fightercraft/gunships that follow you around for a 1 time fee. They are very durable, are good fodder, and you can only have 1 with you at any time.    Deflectors are a sort of temporary shield you can activate which absorb damage. You can also ram enemy ships with them to inflict damage.    Defensive capabilities   Include 1) Deflectors 2) Shields 3) Armor 4) Hull 5) Engine boosters    As mentioned, Deflectors are temporary shields that asborb damage until you run out of charge, in which case you must wait for them to have charge in order to use them.    Shields are divided into 4 sections that protect your ship (front, port, starboard, aft) from all damage and collisions.    Armor protects your ship's hull. Damage to armor can damage to ship systems.    Hull is your powercore. If it goes to 0, you die.    Engine boosters can be used to maneuver weapons fire, outrun missiles, outrun foes, and kite enemies.   Combat aside, the graphics are very nice and well optimized. Also, the soundtrack is wonderful, it reminds me of Firefly.  As with any game, there is a bit of a grind involved to gain credits in order to unlock higher tiered ships and equipment. Best way to go about this is doing a bunch of high paying missions (mission payouts generally increase as your overall strength increases) alongside a storyline mission once in a while. Or however you want. Imo the grind doesn't feel like a grind sometimes. It's pretty fun to blow ♥♥♥♥ up.   All in all, I dig it. Combat is different, not shallow. Plenty of content. Good soundtrack. Solid mechanics. Decent plot. Way to go Double Damage Games. I hope you keep making titles in this genre!

This is a pretty good space RPG. Almost all the bounties are combat-type bounties.   You can also acquire money through trade on the commodities market, but it can be very time-consuming. The key to commodities trading is finding out what outposts will pay the highest for various products. For instance, a scientific oytposts will pay higher for intellectual property and tech stuff, but a rogue or outlaw outposts will pay more for illicit drugs and whatnot. You can also gain trading info by reading news boards and speaking to bartenders. Traveling between space stations and various parts of the galaxy can be boring. It can take several minutes to travel between points on opposite sides of the galaxy.  The graphics are nice and the music is awesome, but it gets a little monotonous after awhile since it plays constantly on a loop throughout the entire game.   The combat is interesting. It is 'naval-style' combat, which means your primary guns fire from the side. This imposes a significant learning curve to combat since you have to fight sideways, which makes it harder to see incoming missiles. There are secondary weapons that you can switch to that don't require sideways combat, but then you have to constantly adjust your ship angle if you switch weapons a lot. It is challenging but rewarding when you finally get it all down. This game represents everything that's right about games.  A couple of guys named Erich Schaefer and Travis Baldree put this thing together. Between the two of them, they've had a hand in Fate, Mythos, Diablo II, and Torchlight. If you liked those games, and have played Freelancer or the little known Escape Velocity, this game should be an instant buy. Even if you haven't played space based ARPGs, you should buy this game.  Why? It feels good to play, and everything in the game is secondary to it feeling good to play. That's how it represents everything that's right about games: it focuses on playing as being the critical element. The controls, sounds, and looks of the game come together to make it feel like you're playing something that's meant, designed, and created to be played, above all else.   What really drives the game is the desire to kill things and become space rich, so you can kill stronger things and become even more space rich. It's the drive to kill, loot, and kill and loot even more that keeps the player going.  If you're into narrative heavy games, then you probably should pass on this. The story is campy, and not something that you'll remember for crazy plot twists or complex drama. But it's just interesting enough to keep you moving forward.  Rebel Galaxy has some sim-lite features, though not especially fleshed out. A player can disrupt a trade convoy, which keeps supplies low and prices high at a station. Or they can break through a blockade, and exploit the need for supplies to work towards becoming space rich.  Looking forward, this game provides a solid foundation for further features to be developed. I think this has a lot of potential to become an even better game, with deeper complexities driving the sim-lite features.  Really though, if you played and loved kill & loot driven games like Diablo II & Torchlight, or especially if you have played Freelancer or Escape Velocity... you need to buy this.

Do you like Firefly? Do you like flying around in a ship and blowing stuff up? Then buy this game.  Play as a pirate, smuggler, merchant, miner, mercenary, soldier or any combination you like!  The story is nothing to write home about, but this is mostly a space sandbox anyway. The game itself is absolutely gorgeous and an incredible pleasure to play. There are many different ship types to play around with and different weapon combinations to keep you interested for a good while. The little dinky tugboat you start out with isn't much, but it won't take you too long to throw some bigger guns on it and start slugging it out with the bigger ships.  Ship flight is arcade-style and takes place in faux-3D space: that is to say smaller ships like fighters and bombers (which you don't pilot) fly around in 3D, but the bigger ships, from corvettes to dreadnaughts, stay on a 2D plane. Ships have turrets and you can pick up a hireable strike-craft to help you out, but most of the firepower is concentrated in naval-style broadside weaponry.  Difficulty is mostly linear and is determined by the tier of your equipment, not the size of your ship, so you're not forced to play a huge, sluggish battleship if you don't want to (or don't want to save up for it.) Some people have complained about the 'risk estimate' for certain missions being a little inaccurate, but I haven't really had any issues with it provided I upgrade my equipment properly and am not afraid to bug out when the going gets tough.  Default soundtrack is great - a pleasureable selection of hard rock music that fits the tone of the game. You can add your own music, or replace the whole soundtrack altogether if you want. Controls are smooth, with the occasional futzing required with overlapping cargo containers (protip: use your targetting scanner to lock onto the container you want.) Graphics are absolutely stunning and the sound effects are top notch.  Definitely worth picking up this gem!

Have you ever been attracted to the IDEA of space sims, but been unable to figure out impossibly dense controls? Do you love the IDEA of piloting a massive battleship into battle, but can't deal with stupid 3D loop-de-loops? Do you just like pretty explosions and badass slide guitar music?  Then this game is for you.  It's a pretty standard space game setup-- fly around the galaxy trading, mining, fighting, what have you. Upgrade your ship, buy progressively bigger and badder ships, rule the world, and so on. The twist is that it all takes place on a 2D plane. Objects float around and ships-- especially fighters-- fly every which way, but you only have to worry about one dimension. The basic play is pretty much like Assassin's Creed 4: Black Flag. You hold down the button to charge a broadside, aim a bit and fire; hit your shields to brace for impact before taking return fire, and so on. There's a bit more, with turrets and different weapon types and hired mercenaries, but that's the basic idea. It's easy to get the hang of and fun to play. And, you know, it looks pretty, the soundtrack is great, and it's nice to have a third person view of your ship instead of trying to make sense of things from a cockpit view.  tl;dr: If you want to fly a battleship in space without wrapping your head around complex controls, this is for you.

A fantastic title if you're looking for a robust starship sim. You select your craft from a wealth of options that range from a speedy corvette-class vessel to a dreadnought bristling with a dozen turrets. Combat is reminiscent of naval warfare, where you try to position yourself to blast your foes with powerful broadside weaponry and the options for arming yourself are truly staggering. You can arm your ship with particle beams, mines, flak cannons, missiles, anti-matter cannons, pulse turrets... there's an option for every playstyle and you can sink hours into perfecting your unique ship.  There's a wealth of content to be had but the downside is that a lot of it can grow repetitive. Upgrades for your ship don't come cheap and as difficulty spikes can be quite jarring you'll find yourself doing a lot of the same basic missions over and over again to get yourself up to snuff. The mechanics themselves are a joy, though, which really helps to ease this shortcoming and the moment to moment opportunities for profit allow you to choose between piracy, mercenary activity or just plain honest trade.  All in all, if you're looking for a space sim that will spoil you for choice, Rebel Galaxy is the game for you.

Charming and addictive game. Yes its 2D space. There is no up and down flying. And the sytems are full (sun, planetes) but compressed in space. So there are traveling times, but they're not too long and nicely balanced, focussing more on fun and flowthen on realism.  Generally the flow and speed of the game is very very good.  Battles feel very much like the ship battles in Assassins Creed Black Flag. The 'Space' like a big, flat ocean. Additionally a freelancer like universe with many systems, multiple ships, in many sizes with different focus. Some only avalable from factions like mercenaries or trading guild. A large variation of weapons and equipment, boots, boosters, shields for different play and fight stlyes. Shields and boosters for example are not only different in hitpoints or speed but there are versions with completely different focus.  It's therefore nicely complex and flexible. And a smart buy/sell systems mean you can try without really goin 'wrong' or being punished for experiments. With possible problems, concerning difficulty, mentioned below.  Having finshed the Main Story: It's not a storytelling masterpiece.  But it's good enough, nicely presented, fully and professionally voiced, and leads through the first systems of the 'universe' and the factions in it.  Before i go to some details and little complaints, please keep in mind:  Its a fun little (its actually pretty big) game for a RIDICULOUS low price. Just dont expect a full 6 axis Space sim! It's a space based action game with strong freelancer elements in it.  I FULLY recommend it. Even for a higher price it would be a very good game! _____________________________   That being said :a few general remarks, only some bordering on complaints:  Like Assassins creed Black flag, which the fighting is CLEARLY inspired from, i find it a lot easier and more intuitively and precisely to control with MOUSE then with a gamepad. Both is available though, both works good.  My joystick (tm hotas) doesnt appear as option though.  After the Story there are still missions from boards to perform. Leveling up in factions to gain access to better ships. And trading. However for the trading the small selections of goods and the ship designs don't seem perfect. It doesn't really lend itself well to that. However i didn't really play like that so i might be wrong. There is a merchants guild in which you can level up, getting unique, trading focussed ships. But i think i can say, the focus of the game clearly is on the fights. And it excels in that!  The 100% system behind the upgrades makes it maybe a bit easy, as there are no hard choices to make. But it makes it also more fun to play. If you buy the wrong upgrade or a weapon you dont like, just sell it for the full price. No wrong ways, no saving money while flying with a weak ship, just to be able to afford something better later. I like that a lot, some might find it not challenging or complex enough though.  The same for the energy system. Basically nothing limits the size of shields and weapons in a ship. The only reason preventing you from upgrading hull and shields even in the smalles ships is the price. And the value of Damage absorption of shields, hulls, deflectors ( short period shields for emergencies) is the SAME, even in the smallest ship. If you put (you cant afford without cheat) a mk3 or 4 shield in your starter ship, you'd be immortal in the first systems. Heavy hull and Shields should be limited to big ships, given that they would consume more energy then a small ship can provide. Or provide less hitpoints in smaller ships. But they don't. I think that system would benefit from more complexity.  The mission log is too small. Should have room for a few more missions (quests). ________________________  Little tips from my experience, they're of course only MY opinion:  1.Mining lasers are op. They imho the best weapon ingame AND can mine asteroids (which isn't profitable enough as a main profession). They make good damage to shields AND hull. The other laser makes somewhat more damage to hulls but very little to shields. They simply make NO sense. Having a ship with all turrets mining lasers is (in range) the best. And you dont run out of ammo like with rocket launchers. small capacities of ammo make them near pointless. Disadvantage is the range, but i found my self that close to enemies all the time anyway.  2. In the first systems, in the beginning, as soon as you can, fly to the next system, even if it's too high-level for you to fly missions in, rush to a station, avoiding all fights, and buy the BETTER shield available there.  Even if you have to stick to cheaper wepons for a while to be able to afford it. Remember, selling those weapons later you get 100%of your money back to invest in bigger ones..  Then go back to the previous system where fights are MASSIVELY easier if you have that better shield. Every higher shield MK doubles the shields hitpoints. No matter how small the ship is.  The same works technically with weapons. Mining laser (and other weapons) MK1>MK2 is a MASSIVE jump in damage (and a small one in range). But very expensive. Shield should be #1 priority. Generally: the jump in difficulty from the first to the second system is the highest. The first basically is an easy going tutorial system. 2-3 is also quite big. After that it's much less steep.  3. Fighting big ships: dont fly into their broadsides of course. Search dead angels and stick there, firing at it. Flying in its engine (does no damage to you) it can't hit you and you can fire. Discovering that made those fights vs capital ships A LOT EASIER for me.  4.Entering and leaving stations saves your game. Having a little detour between missions to do that is worth the time. Dying in the 4th consecutive mission, losing all you got from the last 3 can be VERY annoying.

This wears out pretty quickly though and I find myself wishing they would throw more at me to match the level of my ship.  Once the storyline is finished I don't feel there is a lot of replayability, there's no real 'other' way to play the game except as maybe an outlaw, which will severely limit the number of stations you can visit and missions you can take.  The positives, I think, far outweigh the negatives. Brief: -------Very decent sandbox space shooter, full of charm and visually beautiful.-------   Pros:  The soundtrack is spot on, fits the bill to a T for all fans of Cowboy Beebop and the like. Fight the bad guys or skirt the law, it suits both perfectly.  Graphics are wonderful, the backgrounds are easy on the eye, the laser and engine effects are beautiful, and the asthetics of the ships, stations and other objects are up to par.  The atmosphere you get from jetting from one point to the next gives you the sense that its a lonesome place out there, and even though you meet npcs frequently, there's no way to shrug off the lone wolf vibe. Both good and bad, but certainly most of the time feels great.  Combat is tight. The whole game works on a 2D axis, which at first I thought would be missing a huge opportunity to give the space combat its full potential, but in truth it simplifies it enough that you never really get the feeling of being overwhelmed; it is straight forward, easy to master, and never really gets dull when you're fighting at your level or something tougher.   Cons: The NPCS feel bland. In over 8 hours of gameplay so far I've yet to meet any characters that I can say stuck in the memory or that I really liked. You could replace any of them very easily and wouldn't feel a loss of any sort.   The story hasn't got me hooked thus far, I don't particularly care about the objectives being laid out before me, nor the people who are integral to it. This could be because everything early game plotwise has been done many times before, the characters, dialogue and scenario all feel as though they've been lifted out of several other titles/stories the writers or developers have experienced and put together for their own project.  Occassionally travelling can be frustrating. Sometimes the large distances can be boring, though in truth adds hugely to the atmosphere of the vastness, so a double edged sword. However getting interupted from your warp because of misc objects is irritating, making me think warp lanes or shipping lanes might have been a nice addition.  I also feel the developers missed a trick not including simple add ons like being able to hire your own crew, making a diverse mix of aliens or humans to operate your ship, needing more the larger the vessel you acquire. It would have been a great opportunity aswell to put in some excellent personalities and vary up the dialogue during fights. That said, it would serve to remove the lone wolf feeling. You can hire your own merc to help out in the fighting, but can't really interact with them at all; no dialogue to get to know them or character development, just one liners from them saying if they're taking fire or going on the attack.  Overall: All in all, it is a brilliant and fun game. The lack of a killer story (at least early on) or solid characters doesn't detract from the fact that it is visually stunning and just flat out fun to play. I bought it the night of its release day and haven't really been able to put it down for wanting to get a better ship, better guns and take them into combat.   For those who love a space setting, bounties, smuggling and everything that goes with the territory, this is well worth the pricetag to kill some time. Better ships to buy, choose your own armaments and enhancements, join factions and improve your standing with them. Its a well put-together space sim.

Rebel Galaxy is a sandbox space sim from two of the guys who brought you Diablo, Hellgate: London, FATE, Mythos and Torchlight, Travis Baldree and Erich Schafer. After so many years working on isometric action-rpgs, the pair cooked up something a little different. Rebel Galaxy is a tale of space cowboys and pirates set on the fringes of known space. Your aunt Juno Markev has asked you to come out to her neck of the woods to help her out with something. And I'm not saying its aliens, but it is definitely aliens. The flavor of the setting has been compared several times to Firefly, and I'm inclined to agree. The ships are scratched up and very spartan in design, there are bandits, merchant caravans and lawmen, and combat is up close and personal, accompanied by a blusey hard rock soundtrack including Blues Saraceno's 'Evil Ways'. But Rebel Galaxy differs from many space sims you may have played before in two very big ways: one, the entire game is on a 2D plane. You steer your ship with the left stick and aim your guns with the right, which brings me to the second big part- your strongest guns are mounted on the sides of your ship, which I should add, is no mere snubfighter or freighter. No, you begin the game with a corvette, and purchase increasingly larger and better armed ships all the way up to a fearsome dreadnought. The biggest fights are close up, harrowing exchanges of cannon fire like you were in an old pirate movie, or more accurately, the Harlock series. And ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ is it fun. Some reviews I've read have knocked this 2d plane element, and I can understand where they're coming from, but I think it lends Rebel Galaxy a certain 'space is an ocean' feel that only helps the overall premise. One particular reviewer said something along the lines of 'it might as well be about truckers in a desert' which, upon reflection, would be a pretty badass game too. At any rate, you can also have a number of turreted weapons including ballistics, lasers and missiles, as well as a secondary weapon like auto-tracking missiles or fighter-disabling EMP flak guns, and you can designate auto-targeting priorities for your turrets so you can focus on firing your broadsides. You can hire a mercenary gunship to back you up, loot, buy and sell commodities at the station markets or with passing merchants, pirate said merchants or defend them from other raiders, take side missions, hunt for bounties and pirate lords, break blockades, mine asteroids, and join merchant or mercenary guilds. You can also outfit your ship with various specialized subsystems that allow you to, for example, accurately target incoming torpedoes or convert missile damage to your shield into more shield strength. Your actions affect your reputation with the citizenry, the militia, and various pirate factions, A series of story missions take you from one side of the sector to another, and each mission, main or side, is marked with its 'risk level' allowing you to judge whether to take it on your take some time to upgrade your equipment first. In some ways, Rebel Galaxy is a bit barebones. I played it for almost 40 hours and enjoyed most of it, but you will see most of what the game has to offer after the first 5 or so. From that point on, its mostly about buying bigger ships, more guns, and fighting larger groups of enemies. The side missions, as in any other space sim, are stock 'go here, shoot this, escort that, collect this' affairs that quickly begin to loop. Thankfully the combat never feels stale, and though you a lot of time early on in warp travel, you can buy faster warp drives as you progress, eventually rendering travel times completely non-annoying. The plot is not nearly as epic as say, Freelancer, but it serves its purpose. If you believe that any time spent grinding is time wasted, then Rebel Galaxy might not be for you, but if you see some grinding as a part of the experience, and enjoy space sims or shooters, Rebel Galaxy is worth your time, especially for the price.

So no more running; I aim to misbehave. - Mal, Firefly  I had this game on my wishlist for quite some time and I honestly couldn't bring myself to buy it. I do enjoy spacey-shootey things, but that whole 'it's kinda like naval warfare' gameplay was not really convincing me. So it was on sale several times, and every time I saw that 'game on sale' email I was like 'yay' and then 'oh, rebel galaxy, hm'. Finally, a few days ago I was so bored that I thought I'd give it a try, keeping in mind the lenient return policy, so what could go wrong?  Well, for starters, I was wrong. This game is more fun you than I could have ever imagined, especially for that price.  But let's begin with the cons, since that is always what I like to read first. While the graphics are really nice, the character models are sub-par. Then again, they might have invented cloning in that universe, so it might be perfectly natural to have a gazillion space stations with the same bartender. or he's working more than other people. Bartending doesn't pay much, after all, so yay for realism.  It also is a bit of a grind to get started, no way of cheating your way to a better ship. While that is not necessarily a con, it does mean that you spend your first few hours desperately trying to find a station that buys yourt goods for the highest price, or you do missions which dont pay that much in the beginning.  My last issue, if you can call my ♥♥♥♥♥ing that, would be that I truly and honestly miss a way to see which turret is placed where on the ship, because you might end up buying something super duper heavy hitting laser gizmo thing, and then you wonder why you never see it firing. Well, you might just ended up placing it underneath your ship, and since not many enemies go there (they better not, the buggers), it's not of much use there.   Now, the whole game is so much fun, I ended up playing it till VERY late at night, something I rarely do, simply forgetting the time. Want to be a fighter for good? a pirate? merchant? all of these? well you can, nothing is ever set in stone and you can more or less do what you want. trading is done well, a stations have fluid demands and you can't just always buy and sell at the same stations. 'Events' kind of help you plan a little, but not in a gamebreaking way. . So that keeps it interesting. Fights are fun and not always easy even with good weapons, sometimes you might need to run from them and come back later when you geared up. Special drops sometimes give you that edge you need, some special weapon or gear you cant buy, also a nice touch. The whole ship/speed/damage/defense whatchamacallit is easy enough to understand, but complex enough to keep it fun.  But while the game as a whole simply works and is super entertaining, the soundtrack is the real selling point here. You constantly feel like you are part of the firefly 'verse' and boy, they just nailed it with it. Also, if you don't like it, though you are clearly weird if you dont, they let you use your own music to listen to while you blast huge dreadnoughtships to smithereens.  Rebel Galaxy is one of those few examples of bought for ten bucks, would have gladly paid fifty.

Now this is what I like. Riding into combat guns blazing with music blasting out of the speakers. So far so good. The game is very good, it looks good it plays reasonably well. I don't mind the 2D setting, since it would probably just be a mess in full 3D, like som many other space-games. The story is excellent and even if the ending is a bit on the low key, it does seem appropriate. The game itself gives you different ways to live your life. You can be a priate, a stickler for the law, or something inbetween. I will raise a couple of points on the negative side though. The game is based around fixed values in equipment. In other words if you have hull plating absorbing 10K damage, it will be 10K damage no matter what size ship you have. Same with weapons, and shields. This means that having a natural progression up the available ships gradually increasing in size, is in fact a terrible idea. This sice all your are doing in buying a bigger ship is making yourself a bigger target. If things scaled with the ships this would be a good idea, but as it is it's not, just find yourself a fast ship with good amounts of ports, and upgrade the equipment to max, and you're set. Second negative point is that once you've done the story, there really isn't much to do, the sandbox in which it is set isn't very varied, same type missins with the same type people. However don't let these things discourage you from getting the game, since it is still awsome for those 30-40 hours it will take you to complete the story, which isn't bad for a game these days.  Pluses: Playstyle. Graphics. Awsome Soundtrack. Good storyline. Freedom. Pasting aliens with your guns.  Minuses: Static values for equipment. Limited play after completion.

It's fun. Kind of like Freelancer (due to space pirating and feel) + Firefly (due to space cowboy atmosphere) + AS4: Black Flag (due to naval style combat). Not at all like X series due to you not owning any stations or other ships.  I haven't made out of the first system at the time of writing, so I've only seen a limited part of the game. You fly around doing missions, killing bad guys (or good guys), and upgrading your ship. You gain reputation with various factions as you do so and advance the story.  Story missions are difficulty gated: you won't be able to complete the objectives if your ship is not powerful enough. So you do side missions, random encounters, trade, mine to earn money and upgrade your ship.  The combat is not really challenging or deep, but interesting enough to keep you playing. It's chill, relaxing.  The music is cool, but gets repetitive quick. I wish they included more tracks.  Overall I think it's money well spent.
